COUNTRY AND SECTORAL BACKGROUND THE COUNTRY AND ITS RECENT ECONOMiC DEVELOPMENT 1.1 A landlocked country with a land area of 29,800 square kilometers and a population of 3.75 million, Armenia has few natural resources and its people have survived through strong traditions of education and entrepreneurship. Following the breakup of the former Soviet Union (FSU) and its independence in 1991, Armenia inherited a distorted, inefficient and obsolete national economy strongly affected by the collapse of the central planning system and disruption of traditional trading arrangements within the FSU. The consequent economic and social problems were compounded by the continuing impact of the devastating 1988 earthquake, and by virtual economic siege which resulted from the political conflicts in Georgia and the dispute with Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh. These conditions precipitated a catastrophic decline in output (estimated to have dropped by 52 percent in 1992 and a further 15 percent in 1993) accompanied by hyperinflation which accelerated to 900% in the last two months of 1993. 1.2 Since 1994 Armenia has made huge strides in reforming its economy and in establishing a suitable policy framework. The stabilization program, sustained since early 1994, reduced the budget deficit to 8 percent of GDP in 1996, one sixth of the 1993 figure. Annual inflation has fallen to 6% in 1996. After years of collapse, GDP grew by 5.4 percent in 1994, by nearly 7 percent in 1995 and by a further 5.8 percent in 1996, when per capita GNP was estimated at US$ 830. The core of the Government's reform program has been stimulation of the private sector. Privatization has proceeded quickly, with almost all agricultural land, 80 percent of small enterprises and about 65 percent of medium and large enterprises privatized to date. Prices have been liberalized, and most consumer subsidies have been removed. Clearing trade arrangements have been eliminated, and the foreign exchange and trade regime liberalized. 1.3 From 1992 to 1994, living standards fell sharply and poverty became widespread and severe throughout the country, especially among urban residents without recourse to subsistence agriculture. Although Armenia has no official poverty line, the household survey in 1994 made clear that applying any plausible absolute poverty line resulted in a large majority of respondents being classified as poor. Living standards of the population have yet to recover from the collapse in real wages, compounded by the removal of subsidies on essential goods and drastic cuts in spending on social services. Positive growth since 1994 has allowed a slight recovery, but real wages, at US$20 per month, are still only one third of their level in 1992. Although comparable data are not available for earlier periods, there are strong indications that the fall in living standards for a large proportion of the population has been accompanied by increasing inequality in the distribution of income.
 2 B. THE GENERAL EDUCATION SECTOR 1.4 Education in Armenia, based on 1,600 years of literary heritage, has long been regarded as the main factor in maintaining national identity. When Soviet power was established in Armenia in 1920, a new system of education was introduced, managed centrally from Moscow and based on socialist values. The existing network of Christian schools was reformed accordingly but the Armenian language was basically preserved. Compulsory education was progressively extended from four grades in 1930 to eight by 1959. Teachers at all levels of education received salaries close to the national average income and enjoyed high social status. Pupil drop-out and repetition rates were negligible. At the time of the break-up of the Soviet Union, Armenia enjoyed one of the highest standards of education among the republics, with universal access to ten years of basic education. The great majority of the Armenian adult population is bilingual and literate in both Armenian and Russian and 25% are university graduates. 1.5 The system inherited from the Soviet era now comprises 1,470 primary-secondary schools serving 606,000 pupils with a pupil/teacher ratio of I 1, as well as some 1,070 pre-schools. After up to four years of pre-school, children enter primary school at the age of seven. Funding for pre-school education now comes from a combination of state funds and parental contributions, while primary-secondary schooling, comprising eight compulsory grades and two furither years on the basis of selective examination, is still free of charge, at least in principle. The country also has a number of boarding and special schools, as well as schools offering specialized instruction in music, art or sports. A declining proportion of the children who leave school at grade 8 continue their education in separate technical vocational schools. Less than one percent of primary-secondary pupils attend private schools; however, the use of private tutors outside. school hours is a conmmon practice among those who can afford it. .1.6 Public funding for education has collapsed since independance. In the late 1980s, education expenditure was supported by the general budget of the Soviet Union at an estimated average unit cost across all levels equivalent to approximately US$500-600. The first budget of independant Armenia in 1992 was based on a per student allocation for general education of a mere US$24; in the 1997 budget, this is still very low at about US$30. As a share of GDP, public expenditure on education in Armenia has fluctuated around 2.5% over the last three years--only about half the world average, in part because of the small share of fiscal revenues in GDP. Even as a share of total government expenditure, however, Armenia has been spending well below average on education. (Evolution of the structure and funding of the education system is outlined in Annex 2.) 1.7 The collapse of public funding, combined with the impact of the 1988 earthquake, has undermined quality, demand and equity throughout the education system. Parents are meeting higher costs through informal charges, even for "compulsory" basic education, while the quality of services is declining. The impact has inevitably fallen on those families most affected by transitional poverty who are unable to afford the costs of textbooks, formal and informal fees, private tutors or, in some cases, even the costs of winter clothing and shoes. The longer term implications are recognized to be serious (1 996 Armenia Poverty Assessment), both for the potential emergence of structural poverty in the country, and for the quality of human capital on which Armenia's economy will continue to be highly dependent. 1.8 Between 1990 and 1996, total enrolments across all sectors declined by some 20% while official demographic data report a small increase in the size of the school-age population. Changes in enrolment rates (see Annex 1) are difficult to estimate, however, because the high rates of recent temnporary and permanent migration cannot be accounted for accurately. The most substantial retraction has been in kindergarten, in which total enrolment has fallen by more than 50% and the number of schools by 18% since the late 1980s. This is attributed primarily to the deterioration of facilities, the introduction of charges
 3 to parents, and the high level of unemployment which has made it easier for children to be cared for at home. 1.9 Primary-secondary schools have been forced to close during the coldest months of recent winters and have depended for their survival on parental contributions, the determined efforts of teachers who have received only nominal salaries, and assistance from humanitarian agencies. In compulsory general education, it is estimated that about 5%' of the reference population are not enrolled in school (compared with virtually 0% in the 1980s), while a much higher proportion have not been attending regularly, due largely to the poor physical conditions in schools, and the increasing costs to parents. Total recorded enrolments in 1996 were 1.5% below their 1990 level. Remarkably, the number of schools and the number of teachers have actually increased (see Annex 2), although average qualifications of the teaching force have declined and there are shortages in some subjects. Pupil/teacher ratios (11.1) and average class size (<20) continue to be very low by international standards; by comparison with OECD countries, the excess of non-teaching staff working for the education sector in Armenia is even greater. 1.10 Although the structure of the education budget (Annexes land 2) still shows the influence of the former Soviet norms, it is moving in the direction of standards more typical in market economies. Recent evolution of the budget reflects increasing priority to primary and secondary education; the planned allocation of 51% of the education budget to general education in 1997, up from 41% in 1996, compares with an OECD average of 70%. The shares of the education budget allocated to kindergarten, out-of-school institutions, food, and student stipends, are still high by international standards, despite recent cutbacks. Resources allocated over recent years to new construction, maintenance of existing facilities, or purchase of new equipment, have been negligible. Salaries, which typically account for some 70% of education budgets, are planned to increase to 52% of Armenia's 1997 budget for the sector. 1.11 The responsibility for provision of pre-school and out-of-school services has been transferred in 1997 to municipalities, which receive a lump sum from the central treasury to be allocated as they see fit. Funds for basic schooling are channeled directly from the central treasury to the 11 Marz (regional) education offices. This new level of regional administration is a consolidation of the 57 former regions and represents a deconcentration rather than decentralization of authority: Marz officials are not elected but are appointed by and accountable to the central government. Marz education departments are responsible for disbursing funds to individual schools, on the basis of centrally determined line item budgets, and for managing the regional school inspectorate. The responsibilities of school principals have increased since independence and now include the selection and hiring of teachers and other staff. They have also increased de facto, in that principals have had to innovate in raising resources from other sources, including informal charges to parents, in order to keep schools in operation. The only institutions still managed directly by the Ministry of Education and Science are the boarding and special schools, and some of the post-secondary institutions. The MoES is also responsible for curriculum and textbook development, teacher training and qualifications, and for monitoring and assessment. C. KEY ISSUES Oualitv 1.12 Underfunding. Reversing the decline in the quality of general education will require an increase in the allocation of funds in the State budget.  4 terms of share of GDP, share of government expenditure, the imnmediate needs of the basic education sector, and the resources required for introducing pedagogical reforms. Achieving adequate funding to improve quality will also depend on mobilizing additional non-budgetary resources. Mechanisms are needed to encourage, formalize and target community and parental contributions to schooling; these are already substantial but are largely informal and indirect. 1.13 Physical infrastructure. One consequence of the recent underfunding, combined with the impact of the 1988 earthquake, has been the drastic deterioration of school buildings, in many cases to the extent that leaming is impeded and in some cases presenting health hazards. About one third of Armenia's schools were destroyed or damaged by the earthquake and another 60 by shelling in the border zone. Many schools are still housed in temporary buildings and about one in four permanent structures are estimated to need urgent attention.The majority of schools have no functioning heating system and still depend on inadequate kerosene heaters which were intended only as a short term emergency measure during the energy crisis. Furniture and equipment are grossly inadequate after six years of negligible funding for repair, replacement or upgrading. Some progress has been made in school rehabilitation through the Social Investment Fund, the Earthquake Zone project and assistance from the Diaspora; however, this has been very limited in proportion to the needs. 1.14 Teachers 'pay and incentives. Teachers have been receiving only nominal salaries, equivalent to about $12 per month in 1996. Combined with the exceptionally difficult teaching conditions, this has resulted in an outflow of qualified and experienced teachers (including almost all male teachers), a decline in the average level of qualifications in the teaching force, and shortages of teachers in some subjects. Tlhose who remain in the profession are obliged to supplement their income through private tutoring and through other activities such as trade or subsistence agriculture. The status of teachers in the community has declined and teacher training is no longer a popular option among academically successful school leavers and graduates. In-service training of teachers is underfunded and inadequate to support implementation of any significant pedagogical reforms. As development of the labor market is increasing the alternative opportunities available, substantially improved salaries and incentives will be essential to retain and attract high quality teachers. 1.15 Textbooks. Failure of the system for provision of basic textbooks has become a particularly critical issue. Under the Soviet system, pupils were provided with copies of all the required books, on loan for the year, free of charge. Following independence, curricula and textbooks have been progressively revised to remove Soviet ideological bias and reflect Armenian history and culture. Publishing, printing and distribution of new textbooks, however, has been ineffective, because of the shortage of public funds, the lack of experience of financial and commercial management practices on the part of any sector of the Armenian book trade, and failure to control costs, quality or delivery schedules. Since 1992, parents have been required to pay for textbooks. The system introduced in 1995 has been based primarily on parental pre-subscription payments (supported in some cases by public loans) to pre-finance publishing and printing contracts that are awarded by the MoES, without competitive process, on the basis of expected demand. Public opposition to this approach has been strong. The 1996 social assessment revealed that only 30 % of pupils have access to all required textbooks, and the majority of parents consider the availability, cost and quality of textbooks to be the single most important issue for their childrens' schooling. There is an urgent need for an efficient and effective system of textbook provision that is affordable to parents, meets the needs of teachers and pupils, and can support the on-going curriculum reform process. 1.16 Pedagogical approach. A further challenge is the need to adapt curricula and teaching and assessment methods to the needs of students in a market economy. The curricula and methodology inherited from the soviet system are excessively rigid, emphasizing conformity, factual content and rote learning. Teaching is characterized as "directive" or "frontal", with the teacher as the center of activity. It is unusual
 5 for pupils to work on their own tasks at their own pace or to work in groups. In the medium term, the Armenian system needs to move from what is still predominantly a knowledge based methodology to one that will encourage the development of adaptive skills, practical problem solving and individual initiative. This would require a major shift in the focus of teacher training and assessment methodology, from subject content to learning processes. There is still a lack of any clear consensus in Armenia, however, among education professionals or the general public, concerning the nature or urgency of any changes needed in pedagogical approach, in part because of strong concern that the rigorous standards achieved in the past should not be jeopardized. Efficiencv 1.17 School consolidation and rationalization of staffing. In the short and medium term there is a crucial need to address widespread inefficiencies in the system, in particular the unsustainably generous distribution of facilities and personnel, and to reallocate finding to priority areas such as teachers' salaries and training, materials and equipment, and buildings maintenance. Variability throughout the country in class sizes and staffing ratios is extreme, with some primary school classes in small schools, for example, having fewer than 0 pupils. In addition, recent migration has left many school buildings underutilized. T.here is considerable scope for using scarce education resources more effectively by merging schools (especially at the secondary level), selling or renting surplus buildings, increasing pupil/teacher ratios and class sizes, extending teachers' working hours, using multi-grade teaching in small rural schools, and reducing the number of non-teaching staff. The case is also strong--for both cost efficiency and humanitarian reasons--for rationalizing the boarding special school sector and intergrating many of the pupils in local day schools. 1.18 Incentives and mechanisms for efficiency measures. Under the existing structure of school finance and management, which is based on central control through line item budgeting, there are few incentives or mechanisms at any level for identifying and implementing efficiency and quality improvement measures. There is little room for flexibility or innovation in resource allocation at the school or marz levels. In addition, the commitment of central education planners to a program for school consolidation and rationalization of staffing has been deterred by lack of assurance that the resulting savings will be retained in the education sector. Equitv 1.19 Equity in access to education is a matter of increasing concern. Access to post-secondary education is increasingly restricted to the children of well-off families. There is also concem that the children of poor families do not have equitable access to "compulsory" basic education. The 1996 social assessment revealed that informal payments for basic education are high (Annex 4), and that this was an important factor in the non-attendance of a small minority of children and the irregular attendance of many more. Another concern of parents was that, now that most of the professional schools had closed, poor children who failed to meet the academic criteria for entrance to grades nine and ten were often left with no alternative educational opportunity and no practical skills. 1.20 Targeting of subsidies. As informal payments at each level of education are increasingly replaced by formal cost recovery or private provision, the need is well accepted for subsidies to be made available to those who are unable to pay. Formal charges have already been introduced for pre-school, for textbooks and non-core subjects in basic education, for most specialized instruction in out-of-school institutions, and for the majority of post-secondary students. In the absence of accurate income reporting or good proxy indicators of poverty, innovative mechanisms are needed to target subsidies effectively to the neediest pupils. As schools are depending on parental and community support even to meet the costs of the core
 6 curriculum, it will also be necessary to target additional public funding to schools in the poorest communities. istitutional Capacity 1.21 Successful reform and effective management of the education system will require time and resources for capacity building, consultation and consensus building. Armenian education professionals have limited experience in functions that were formerly carried out in Moscow and have been isolated from international debate and exposure to current practice in their field. Knowledge and skills in finance and management are lacking at all levels of education administration. The new institutional framework still lacks consultative mechanisms and transparent processes for decisiomnaking in the sector. Sector analysis and research are made difficult by the past neglect of these functions and by lack of reliable data. Reform is also hindered by vestiges of the soviet management culture in the education sector: the culture of central planning, tendencies among colleagues to withhold rather than share information, the longstanding role of teachers and students as followers of a central mandate, and the role of parents as passive recipients of education services, leaving all school management and pedagogical questions to the professionals. In this context, information will play a particularly key role in the emerging system. D. THE GOVERNMENT REFORM STRATEGY 1.22 The govermment strategy for education reform (Annex 3) is based on improving the quality and efficiency of compulsory general education by providing more autonomy to schools, increasing parents' and community contribution for non core curriculum activities, redirecting public funding to general education, and rationalizing education expenditures. The strategy integrates the following elements: • Increasing public expenditure on education, to at least 10.3% of total non-interest government expenditures in 1998 (under the Structural Adjustment Program). * Concentrating public funds on assuring the quality of eight years of compulsory basic schooling, with a further two years to be provided free of charge on the basis of selective examination. * Expanding formal cost recovery and/or private provision for non-core subjects and services in basic education, and for pre-school and post-secondary programs. * Introducing a new system for textbooks, based on competitive procurement, to support on-going curriculum revision. The system will be self-financing and driven by demand at the school level. * Providing subsidies, to be allocated at the school level, to those who are unable to afford the textbook rental fee or other essential payments. * Rationalizing the allocation of resources within general education through school consolidation on the basis of more cost effective norms and standards for school size, facilities, class size and staffing ratios. * Progressively introducing a new status and governance structure for schools. Autonomous schools would be governed by school boards, including parent and teacher representatives, would receive per pupil budgetary funding (based on new norms and standards for the core curriculum and weighted accorded to special needs), would have the right to raise and manage funds from other sources and to charge fees for "non-core" services, and would determine their own expenditure allocations.
 7 Focusing the role of the central Ministry on curriculum development, setting and monitoring of standards, teacher training and qualifications, assessment of student and school performance. 1.23 A number of changes have already been introduced in the sector. Private participation is already strong in the tertiary sector. Since 1992, primary-secondary school principals have been responsible for hiring and firing teachers and other staff. Charges have been introduced for meals in pre-school and responsibility for the provision of pre-school and out-of-school services has been transferred to municipalities. The 1997 budget reflects the increasing priority of funding basic education. In particular, the new system for competitive textbook procurement has been piloted and the full textbook strategy enjoys broad support within the Ministry, in schools, and among the general public. 1.24 The government's proposed measures for school consolidation and school autonomy are less well understood or supported by key stakeholders, even within the MoES. The Ministry has suffered from a series of changes in leadership, lack of effective internal communication, and shortage of funds for public information activities. Substantial progress has been made in recent months: the MoES document outlining the broad reform strategy (Annex 3) has been finalized and formally endorsed by the government; the government has also adopted a decree re-defining the status of schools and school boards and specifying the procedures and criteria for granting the new autonomous status; and the MoES has carried out an economic study defining more cost effective norms and standards to guide the rationalization process. Nevertheless, building sufficient support to pilot and implement these reforms successfully will be extremely difficult, considering the limited institutional capacity and the dependence at this stage on a few key personnel. The legal basis for the reform strategy has yet to be established. E. RATIONALE FOR BANK INVOLVEMENT hntearation in the CAS 1.25 The project is an integral element in the new CAS (1997) which puts human resources development at the core of proposed Bank support, with the objective of "ensuring social sustainability of the reform process and the alleviation of poverty through improvements in the quality of and access to basic health and education services." This objective, and the proposed project, are also supported in the CAS by Structural Adjustment Credits which give high priority to human resources, and a proposed follow-up social sector adjustment loan for 1999. 1.26 The CAS draws on the poverty assessment (1996) which emphasizes the crucial role of the basic education sector-- in meeting the human capital needs for economic growth, in limiting the danger of longer term structural poverty in Armenia, and in promoting social cohesion. The poverty assessment recommends that high priority be given to improving both the level and the efficiency of public expenditure on education and to concentrating public resources on ensuring universally affordable, good quality, basic education. 1.27 Policy dialogue with Armenia on the education sector has been sustained over the last two years in relation to the Social Investment Fund and the SAC, as well as project preparation. The experience of the SIF in working with communities on school rehabilitation has been positive and has informed the design of this project. The project has been prepared in tandem with a health project which is addressing related reform issues in the financing of basic health services. An IDF grant is proposed to support de- institutionalization of children in special boarding schools and orphanages. 1.28 The specific measures included in the SAC II support the policy framework for the project. The main measures described in the Letter of Development Policy concerning general education are: (i) the Government is committed to not incurring any arrears on education expenditures in the implementation of
 8 the 1997 budget, to ensuring that the share of appropriations to the education sector for the second half of 1997 is no less than 9.3% of total non-interest government expenditures, and that the 1998 state budget to be submitted to Parliament will include an allocation for education of at least 10.3 % of total non-interest government expenditures; (ii) in order to rationalize the use of resources, increase efficiency and improve teacher salaries, the Government will adopt a program for consolidation of schools, defining the norms and standards that will guide the consolidation process, and specifying the mechanisms that may be used to manage the closure or transfer of redundant facilities and associated staff, regional education authorities will be required to draw up their own detailed programs, on the basis of local consultation, and these programs for the first two pilot marzes will be prepared and submitted by December 31, 1997; (iii) to allow the number of boarding schools to be reduced, the Govermnent will adopt, by April 1, 1998, a strategy for de-institutionalization of children in boarding schools and other specialized institutions. Public priorities 1.29 The 1996 social assessment of health and education (Annex 4), undertaken in the course of project preparation, revealed the strength of public concern about the deterioration in basic education services: 50% of respondents in the household survey named education as the number one problem facing the country, while 83% placed education in the top three problems; within education, the biggest concern was overwhelmingly that of textbook supply. Catalytic role 1.30 The government's strategy for education reform is ambitious and would be virtually impossible to finance without external resources. To date, external support to the sector has been very limited and piecemeal. Diasporan support is channeled to the tertiary sector and special needs programs. Agencies that have been providing humanitarian assistance to schools in the form of food, heating fuel and supplies are progressively pulling out, as the emergency is perceived to be over. Preparation of the project has already facilitated donor coordination and the project could continue to play the role of catalyst to attract additional resources from donors and the private sector, by improving the policy framework and strengthening the capacity of the Ministry of Education and Science to manage externally funded projects. The project has been prepared in close coordination with UNICEF, the only major donor active in the field of general education. Five different donors have already contributed funds for book procurement in piloting of the textbook component. UNICEF and UNDP have committed co-financing for the SIP and school level training. UNESCO experts will be participating in the project under UNDP financing. 2. PROJECT DESCRIPTION A. PROJECT GENESIS 2.1 The Government of Armenia requested Bank assistance in Autumn 1995 for the preparation of a project to address the pressing needs of the general education sector. Policy dialogue has been sustained since then, in relation both to project preparation and the SAC. Despite changes of leadership in the Ministry of Education and Science, and lack of consensus on some aspects of reform policy, government conunitment to the proposed project has not wavered.
 9 2.2 Two working groups were established by the Minister of Education, charged with the definition of reform measures and implementation plans. Each group was supported as needed by international consultants with appropriate experience, funded by a country-managed PHRD grant for project preparation. The first group developed the new strategy and implementation plan for textbooks, in coordination with curriculum planners, basing the detailed design on extensive consultation with parents, teachers and principals in each region of the country, as well as key players in the publishing and printing industries. The second group, supported by the development of a computerized management information system in the Ministry of Education, had a broader mandate to prepare the overall strategy for reform of education finance and management. 2.3 Social assessment in project preparation included qualitative and quantitative surveys (in mid 1996) of the experience, opinions and concerns of households, teachers and parents concerning education reform. A national workshop was held in October 1996 to disseminate the findings of the social assessment and debate the reform options. 2.4 A PPF was approved to finance a pilot exercise and related training in textbook procurement. PROJECT RATIONALE AND ALTERNATIVES CONSIDERED 2.5 Project design is influenced by a variety of factors. First, the scale of this initial project in the education sector is constrained by limitations of IDA funding. Second, the potential scope and pace of the education reform process in Armenia depends both on strengthening institutional capacity and on continuing public debate on priorities and reform options in some areas before sufficient consensus is reached for successful implementation. Third is the need for complementarity with related Bank operations in the selection of project components. 2.6 The broad rationale underlying project design is that, considering the immediate funding and institutional constraints, priority should be given to establishing the necessary institutional framework for the management of education reform and for future larger scale investment in the sector. The project therefore targets resources to building management capacity at central, regional and school levels, all of which will be essential in the medium and long run to improve the quality and sustainability of the general education system. For several reasons, this first project is designed to focus in particular on capacity building at the school level: first, this is where most of the recent innovation and dynamism has occurred; second, in the present situation of near crisis, the most rapid short term results can be achieved by focusing on the capacity at this level; third, government's reform strategy will place substantial additional formal responsibilities at the level of the school. 2.7 The project will help to test, establish and build confidence in new institutional roles and decisionmaking processes by focusing on three key areas of the government's reform strategy--textbook provision, school consolidation and school autonomy. Because of the need to pilot new arrangements, considerable flexibility will be called for in project implementation. This, in turn, will put a strong onus on monitoring and social assessment during the course of implementation, which is built into project design. 2.8 The project addresses all of the key issues for the sector outlined in section I.C above, with the exception of the following: Physical infrastructure: The project does not address the very substantial need for reconstruction and rehabilitation of school buildings. It does support the schools consolidation

In addition, a mechanism already exists, through the SIF, for channeling funds for school rehabilitation; it is proposed that other donors be encouraged to contribute to the SIF for education. The community-based approach of the SIF corresponds well with the schools-focused approach in the design of this project, with complementary objectives; there will be close coordination between the SIF and the pilot schools improvement component. * Teachers pay, training and incentives: This is another issue of crucial importance. However, the need here is for recurrent rather than investment funds and it is proposed that this be addressed under a future social sector adjustment loan. In the meantime, the present SAC conditions on budgetary allocations to education, combined with reductions in the number of staff under the rationalization program, should allow for some improvement in this area. * Pedagogical reforms: The proposed project is addressing the "process" issues related to curriculum reform and textbook evaluation, through the textbook component. However, it is not directly addressing important questions of curriculum content, or teaching methods. The social assessment suggests that, in the current crisis situation, neither parents nor teachers in general are keen to experiment with new pedagogical methods which might threaten the traditional standards in which they take pride. At the same time, Armenians feel strongly that this is a national matter which they have the capacity to deal with themselves. The project will, however, include measures to increase exposure of educators to new ideas and make information available on international practice. It is envisaged that dialogue will be sustained on these questions and that the financial needs for implementing reform of teaching and assessment methods, once there is sufficient consensus on the need for this, could be met through a subsequent project to finance the development of teacher training systems. 2.9 The strategic focus of the project is twofold: * facilitating improvements in the quality of general education by promoting school-level initiatives, by increasing opportunities and incentives for innovation throughout the system, and by improving the supply of textbooks and teaching materials; * helping build the necessary institutional framework and capacity at all levels, for more efficient, equitable and sustainable operation of the basic education system. DESCRIPTION OF PROJECT COMPONENTS Component I: Improve Textbook Production and Distribution (US$ 16.9 million) 2.12 Since the withdrawal of public funding for textbooks in 1992, these costs have been transferred to parents. The combination of high book prices and lack of availability, because of failures in procurement and distribution systems, has led to a situation where less than one third of pupils have access to the books they need. In response to this crisis and the strength of public concern, the Textbook Working Group of the MoES has developed a comprehensive new strategy and implementation plan for procurement and financing of textbooks for the core curriculum. In Novemberl 996, this strategy was approved and adopted by the government. 2.13 The new strategy is based on the following principles: the introduction of publishers' competitions for textbook procurement; the payment of rental fees by parents for book loan; the accumulation of these payments in revolving funds at the school level; and the shift over time to a demand-based system in which schools make their own decisions concerning textbook priorities. The strategy assumes external funding for the purchase of textbooks during the first four years of the new scheme, to enable sufficient funds to be accumulated in schools' revolving funds for the system to become self-financing. A computerized system will be introduced to consolidate the orders from individual schools. In addition, successful implementation of the strategy will require substantial TA, training and information dissemination to ensure that all those involved--administrators, curriculum developers, authors, publishers, printers, distributors, school directors, teachers, parents and pupils--have full understanding of the new procedures. 2.14 ' The 1996 social assessment revealed a high level of public support for the new strategy which is the result of wide consultation with school principals, teachers and parents. The strategy is also strongly supported by other donors, five of whom have contributed co-financing in 1997 for the purchase of primary grade textbooks to be included in the first year of the revolving fund scheme. 2.15 Each school will charge book rental fees to parents, based on the anticipated replacement cost of the book after four years (a book life of four years is assumed) and will accumulate the funds in a separate account. The required fee will be calculated and announced annually by the MoES. By the end of the four year period, the system will be self sustaining as schools use their revolving funds to purchase new books and continue to top up the funds from rental fees. During the life of the project, the rental fees collected by each school will be held in separate, interest bearing sub-accounts of a central holding account in Yerevan, in a commercial bank in Armenia. This central fund will be managed on behalf of the schools by the Board of Trustees of the Textbook Fund, which has been registered for this purpose as an extra-budgetary, non- profit, legal entity, legally separate from the MoES but working in close cooperation with it. Once the scheme is operating successfully and is self-financing, it is intended that individual schools may opt to manage their own funds in local accounts. Assurances were received during negotiations that the Borrower will maintain the Textbook Fund as the agent responsible for managing revolving fund accounts during project execution. Reversing the recent deterioration in general education in Armenia will require major systemic reforms. The existing allocation of buildings, teachers and other staff to general education in Armenia is highly generous and is unsustainable under present and projected levels of funding. Many schools have idle capacity while some are overcrowded. In addition, there is great variation between schools and even between regions in class sizes and staffing ratios. The first crucial element under the reform strategy, therefore, is a rationalization program which will ensure more efficient use of buildings and staff, on the basis of revised norms for staffing ratios, teaching hours, and size of classes and schools. 2.29 The MoES has carried out a study which provides the basis for detailed planning and implementation of staffing rationalization and school consolidation; its report includes definition of the recommended new norms and standards and analysis of the potential savings from implementing these standards. LINKAGE wITH ESW AND CAS 5.1 As explained in section 2.B, the proposed project is an integral feature of the new CAS for Annenia (1997), which gives high priority to the objective of ensuring social sustainability of the reform process by improving the quality and coverage of basic education and health services. In recomnmending this emphasis in Bank support, the CAS draws on the findings of the poverty assessment (1996), education sector analysis commissioned in 1995, a public expenditure review (1996) and 3 years of active policy dialogue on the social sectors in Armenia with, in particular, an important social sector component in the Structural Adjustment Credits (SAC I and SAC II). The CAS endorses the government's broad policy for reform of the education sector. 5.2 Key issues identified by the CAS in the sector include: raising the level of funding to general education; reallocating resources within the sector to increase efficiency and concentrate public funding on compulsory general education; making services more demand driven and encouraging private sector participation; using resources more effficiently through school consolidation, reductions in staff/student ratios. The government has already made progress in some of these areas and is now proposing major reforms in the finance and management of general education, to rationalize the deployment of buildings and staff, and to devolve financial and management responsibilities to the school level. However, these reforms are virtually impossible to implement within existing institutional and funding constraints. The CAS includes Bank support to the reform of the general education system through both project and sectoral adjustment lending (see section 1.E).
 27 B. BENEFITS--COST EFFECTIVENESS--DESIGN ALTERNATIVES 5.3 Selection of project components. Project components have been selected to achieve maximum benefits with the given level of funds in terms of building the necessary institutional framework, processes and capacity to implement the reform strategy and at the same time have a direct rapid impact on pupils access to essential education inputs (textbooks and improvement of schools). The project addresses capacity building needs at all levels--central, Marz and school--but gives most attention to the school level, because this is where the results are needed, where priorities can best be identified, where the primary burden of managerial responsibility is to be placed, and where the chances of success are the greatest. Capacity building will focus on three key areas of the government's reform strategy: textbook provision, school consolidation and school autonomy. The project intervenes in the education system through a combination of supply and demand driven approaches. 5.4 Textbook component. The benefits of the textbook component will be: (i) a sustainable, cost recovering system for provision of textbooks, to be driven ultimately by choices made at the school level; (ii) establishment of stable, transparent and efficient processes for procurement and distribution of textbooks; more competitive and efficient publishing and printing industries; (iii) reduced costs to parents of better quality books; and (iv) access to core textbooks for all pupils. Throughout design of this component, attention has been given to minimizing the costs to parents by reducing the number of required books, improving durability and amortizing costs over an estimated four years. 5.5 Capacity building for reform management component. The benefits of this component will be: (i) an institutional framework and processes for schools rationalisation and for granting of autonomous status to schools; (ii) improved efficiency and sustainability of the general education system through reassessment of building and staffing ratios and reallocation of resources to teachers' salaries, teaching materials and buildings maintenance; (iii) improvement of school performance through incentives to parental and community participation, channeling funds directly to schools, and improving the management and financial skills of principals and school board members; and (iv) improved capacity at the marz and central levels for supporting and monitoring the performance of schools, through training and computerization. Design of the pilot schools improvement program presented a number of trade-offs: a balance was sought between minimizing the costs of administering the fund, spreading the benefits to as many schools as possible, encouraging innovation and initiative in improving the quality of schooling, and building school level institutions. 5.6 Two areas of urgent concern in the general education sector were considered but not included for funding under the project: reconstruction and rehabilitation of school buildings; and improvements in teachers' salaries and training. School construction activities were ruled out because an appropriate mechanism already exists, through the Social Investment Fund (SIF). The project will collaborate closely with the SIF project to coordinate interventions and increase the impact of both projects. The issue of additional funding for teachers' salaries and training is a matter of recurrent rather than investment finance, and the SAC is expected to improve this situation. Another potentially important area is the need for reform of curriculum and teaching methods to focus more on the adaptive skills needed in a market economy. However, there is still strong resistance on the part of many educators and the general public to any changes which might jeopardize traditional standards. Dialogue will be maintained in this field during project implementation, and the transparent processes for development and evaluation of curricula will be established through the textbook component.

RISKS--SUSTAINABILITY 5.7 A significant risk for project implementation and the sustainability of benefits is that changes in the political and administrative leadership in the education sector could impede future actions necessary to implement ambitious systemic reforms. This risk has been reduced by putting the definition of reform strategy and project preparation in the hands of inter-ministerial working groups, which will also be closely involved in project implementation, and by involving other key stakeholders in the dialogue though workshops and conferences. Nevertheless, some aspects of the reform process remain controversial while others are not widely known or understood. There is a risk of effective public opposition to some of the reform measures unless a concerted program of public information and consultation is maintained. Such a program will be supported by the project. 5.8 This risk is smaller for the textbook component, which was designed with the benefit of wide consultation and commands substantial public support. Some specific risks are associated with the textbook component, however. First, budgeted production costs may be insufficient for the books required because of uncertainties in the costing process, in particular the difficulty in predicting world paper prices. In this case either additional funds will be sought or fewer books will be produced. Second, the school- based revolving funds may not accumulate sufficiently, for example if parental contributions do not occur at the predicted rate, or if books fail to last for four years. This eventuality could be addressed in a number of ways, e.g., through annual reassessment of the rental fee or through book-sharing arrangements. Third, genuine competition among publishers and printers may not occur because of the relatively small number of local companies. This risk is considered small, especially in the case of foreign language books, because of the clear interest already displayed by international companies; also, the risk is minimized by intensive training of publishers and bid evaluators, as well as supervision of the procurement process, that is built into the project. In addition, the experience of the pilot phase has fed into design of this component. 5.9 Lack of experience by the MoES in project implementation and competitive procurement also presents a risk which is addressed through provision for substantial TA and training for the PMU. A further risk is that the country's tight fiscal constraints may prevent the government from making the necessary counterpart funds available on a timely basis, thus preventing important project activities from being carried out effectively. Similarly, shortage of funds may prevent key activities from being carried out after project completion. This risk is being minimized by limiting counterpart contributions to a critical minimum--and the constraints may be eased somewhat by the proposed sectoral adjustment loan. D. FISCAL IMPACT--COST RECOVERY 5.10 Sector strategy. The share of total government expenditure allocated to education is planned to increase, in order to achieve adequate funding for universal basic education. The thrust of the government's strategy, supported by the second structural adjustment credit, is to achieve improvements in the quality and sustainability of the general education system by (i) progressive increases in the level of public funding to education, (ii) progressive increases in the share of the education budget devoted to general education (iii) permitting more efficient allocation of funds within the system by consolidation of schools, reassessing staffing norms and giving schools discretion over their own expenditure priorities, (iv) introducing cost recovery for non-core services and (v) facilitating the mobilization of funds from other sources 5.11 Fiscal Impact of the project. The project will create negligible incremental recurrent costs after the project end. The project should however, contribute to a more efficient allocation of funding through the school rationalization component. Theoretically, rationalization of staffing throughout the system on the basis of the MoES' proposed new norms and standards for class sizes and staffing ratios would lead to a reduction of 12% in the number of teaching staff and to estimated overall savings equivalent to about 10%

INSTITUTIONAL ANALYSIS 5.19 The lack of institutional capacity at all levels of education management in Armenia presents the most serious constraint to successful project implementation. It is also the reason for giving such high priority to capacity building in the design of the project. Institutional roles and relationships are frequently unclear, experience is limited, communication is poor, teamwork skills are rare. Major objectives of the project, therefore are to help clarify the new institutional framework, establish consultative mechanisms and transparent processes for making decisions. Preparation and piloting of the textbook component has already made progress in this respect and started to built confidence in the new procedures. The Project Implementation Plan takes account of these issues by specifying roles and functions in detail, and by drawing as many people as possible into the implementation process. There is a particular question of capacity at the school level, to carry the additional managerial and financial responsibilities.  ANNEX 2 Page I of 5 STRUCTURE AND FINANCING OF THE ARMENIAN EDUCATION SYSTEM The Education System Inherited from the Soviet Union Under the Soviet system, Armenian children entered the kindergarten for four years, at the age of three. At the beginning of the 1990s, an estimate of 45% of the reference population were enrolled in 1,200 pre-schools. The language of communication was Armenian but there was no teaching of reading or writing beyond simple recognition of the Armenian alphabet. Children were provided with three or four meals a day, free of charge or at highly subsidized rates. The low pupil- staff ratio and high costs of feeding meant that unit costs were substantially higher than in general education. At the age of seven, children entered the first of eight grades of compulsory general education. About 80% of eighth grade leavers were accepted on merit to the ninth grade for two years of upper secondary education; a minority were enrolled in vocational schools and a small fraction entered the job market and followed evening classes.The vast majority (8 1%) of the country's 1,400 general education schools, including many relatively small village schools, covered all ten grades. Monograde classes were maintained even in the smallest schools, with correspondingly low pupil-teacher ratios. In 1990, about 30% of the 600,000 school-age population were also registered in 105 out-of-school institutions, which provided 4-6 hours a week of specialized instruction free of charge to talented children in technology, art, music or sport. Despite the comprehensive distribution of local schools, Armenia also had a total of 51 generously staffed boarding schools, attended by some 7,000 handicapped children, "socially unprotected" children and orphans, often from pre-school age. Prior to independence, some 47,000 students were enrolled in 101 vocational schools. These provided training to eighth grade leavers in 250 trades, tailored to meet the needs of specific factories in Armenia. A further 50,000 students attended technicums for more advanced training, also geared narrowly to specific positions. Approximately 25% of tenth grade leavers were selected for five years of higher education in Armenia's State university and thirteen institutes, or in institutions in other FSU republics. The number of places in each discipline or trade in all these institutions was determined each year by Ministry of Economy "State Orders" on the basis of planned expansion or replacement needs in each sector. All students in post-secondary institutions received sufficient stipends to cover subsistence and education costs without relying on assistance from their family. Under the Soviet system, all textbooks were developed and supplied from Moscow, with the exception of Armenian language translations of the Soviet books which were handled by one monopolistic state publisher in Armenia. All aspects of the book provision system were centrally controlled, based on formulaic prices, with no competition in quality or price. Every student had a personal copy of each required text, on loan for the year, free of charge. At the time of independence, no sector of the Armenian book trade had any experience of financial and commercial management practices.
 ANNEX 2 Page 2 of 5 Changes since 1991 The collapse of public funding for education following independence, combined with the impact of the 1988 earthquake, has undermined quality, demand and equity throughout the system and has constrained efforts to reform. Between 1990 and 1996, total enrolments across all sectors declined by some 20% while official demographic data report a small increase in the size of the school-age population. There is no evidence of any gender bias in this decline. Changes in enrolment rates are difficult to estimate because the high rates of recent temporary and permanent migration cannot be accounted for accurately. The most substantial retraction has been in kindergarten, in which total enrolment has fallen by more than 50% and the number of schools by 18% since the late 1980s. This is attributed primarily to the deterioration of facilities, the introduction of some charges to parents, and the high level of unemployment which has made it easier for children to be cared for at home. Unit costs have remained high in relation to general education. In the 1997 budget, public funding for pre-school has been cut back and the responsibility for provision transferred to municipalities. Primary-secondary schools have been forced to close during the coldest months of recent winters and have depended for their survival on informal parental contributions, the determined efforts of teachers who have received only nominal salaries, and assistance from humanitarian agencies. In compulsory general education, it is estimated that about 5%' of the reference population are not enrolled in school (compared with virtually 0% in the 1980s), while a much higher proportion have not been attending regularly, due largely to the poor physical conditions in schools, and the inability of some parents to afford informal charges and the costs of clothing and textbooks. Total recorded enrolments in 1996 were 1.5% below their 1990 level. Remarkably, the number of schools and the number of teachers have actually increased (see Annex 9), although average qualifications of the teaching force have declined and there are shortages in some subjects. Pupil/teacher ratios (11.1) and average class size (<20) continue to be very low by international standards. (By comparison with OECD countries, the excess of non-teaching staff working for the education sector in Armenia is even greater). The growth of the private sector at the tertiary level has been remarkable, with 25 new institutions registered in 1996 alone. Most of the entrepreneurs are public university staff who are renting surplus public facilities to carry out their programs. Overview of the Education System 1.1 The history of Armenian literacy dates back more than 1600 years and is closely connected with the Arnenian Christian Church. During 10-15th centuries schools offering 10-12 years of education operated under the Church. The first secular Armenian schools were opened in Armenia in the 18th century. 1.2 The present.system of education was initiated during the short period of the first Republic of Armenia (1918-1920) and was later developed during Soviet power years from 1920-1990. Ten years of compulsory general education in Soviet Armenia was free of charge, coeducational with almost complete enrollment and was about 500-600 US$ state budget allocation per student in the 1980s. The high level of education was the achievement of paramount importance for the Armenian people, which was true for both general and higher education. 1.3 The new Government of independent Armenia inherited a large, powerful and highly centralized education system which incorporated the whole education cycle from preprimary to higher and mainly relied on public funding. 1.4 Currently the education system is facing a number of serious problems, which are the result of the financial and economic constraints of the country and sharp reduction of public funding on education following Independence. As a result, per student allocation from the state budget in 1992 was reduced approximately 25 times in comparison to 1988 and have a little increase up to 1997. However, the current desolate state of schools is determined not only by the scarcity of financial input by the state but also poor adjustment of the schooling system to new realities of life, market economy and open society. 1.5 The maintenance of inherited high level of education and further development of the system ensuring it competitiveness in the international arena is an important national task. There is an obvious need to accelerate the reforms of the education system preconditioned by the processes taking place in the economic and social spheres of Armenia. 2. Reforms 2.1 The reform strategy for general education includes (i) diversification of education financing through concentrating of public funding on core general education and expanding of private expenditures for non-curriculum activities and other levels of education; (ii) structural reforms of the education system including management and finance decentralization, increased autonomy of educational institutions and rationalization of the system, supported by a new informational-analytical system; (iii) continuous improvement of curriculum and teaching methods and the upgrading of knowledge evaluation in consistence with international educational standards.
 ANNEX 3 Page 2 of 5 3. Financin2 of the General Education System 3.1 In 1996, 10,941 billion drains were spent from the state budget in education. For 1997, 12,153 billion drams are planned for education. Continuing increases are expected in budget allocations to education. However, even under the most optimistic scenario of growth of the budget, it will not be possible to cover all costs related to the compulsory core curriculum for many years. 3.2 Meanwhile, the Government's objective for state education over the next years is to ensure universal access to basic general education and provision of free compulsory eight years education for each child with a further two years to be provided free of charge on the basis of selective examinations. This can be done by making more effective use of public funding through precise definition by the Government of grades and subjects according to the core curriculum, targeting of budget funding to this core curriculum and to ensuring equity in the system, and through certain rationalization of the education system as described in the point 6.2. 3.3 The state is not the only performer responsible for education. Citizens also have their own responsibility for education and its expenses. Development of private financing will improve the situation, remove some of the burden from government shoulders, create competitiveness in the sphere. The private tutoring is very much in use in the form of unofficial direct payments to teachers form parents, which indicates the potential that exists in the society and demonstrate the desire of the population to give their children good education. Government intends to legalize these payments, and to introduce or expand the system of official charges for non-core curriculum education within schools and allow for redistribution of the money in the general education. Structural Chan2es and Decentralization 4.1 The important element of the general education reform is the transformation of schools from budgetary institutions to legal entities with the right to hold their own bank accounts and manage their own budgets. Educational institutions will become autonomous and will no longer receive financing per budget lines based on capacity, but will receive financing based on the number of students enrolled in the differential approach in per capita funding by establishment of a per capita funding formula with a weighting index based on poverty level of the community and other special needs. In that case, a higher level of budget funding per student will be granted to some schools, for example, in the earthquake zone, the border regions, remote areas, etc. 4.2 The autonomous institutions will have the right to raise money from other sources and will have freedom in managing their budgets and in deciding how to allocate their resources between different items. The Social Assessment (SA) of the Health and Education Sectors was conducted to provide information to the Government of Armenia about people's attitudes and behaviors regarding utilization, access and satisfaction with education and health services. This SA is only one step in the information consultation process. The SA consisted of both quantitative and qualitative research (interviews and focus group discussions). The main findings are summarized below. Chapter 1: Utilization of Education Services 1. Nursery Attendance: Contrary to general education figures, pre-school attendance is low. While nursery attendance is considered useful by 90 percent of respondents, only 38.9 percent of children 3-7 years old attend a pre-school program. According to respondents, the main reason for explaining low attendance is that "care exists at home." The mean rate respondents were willing to pay (903 drains per month) exceeds the mean monthly current cost for one child (554 drams). 2. School Attendance: In Armenia, all children have the right to ten grades of free education, and 8 grades are compulsory. However the quantitative and qualitative data found that: (1) some school children drop out of school -- not only in the 9th and 10th grades; (2) some are never registered, and (3) many more do not attend school regularly. According to the survey, the rate of non-attendance is 4.6 % of the sample. There were a number of noteworthy trends regarding which students to not attend. Non-attendance affects: o only slightly more urban (54 percent of total non-attending students) than rural students (46 percent); * much more urban students in cities other than Yerevan, than those in Yerevan (ratio: 5:1); m much more boys (6.3 percent of boys) than girls (2.2% of girls); and * mostly students after grade 8. According to the survey, the main reason for not attending school was that children "did not want to attend" (27 percent of responses). Along with "did not want to attend", another top reason for boys was "working to help the family." An important reason for girls was marriage -- which according to the qualitative study is becoming increasingly common after grade 8. The qualitative work also documents cases where non-attendance affected children younger than those in the 9th or 10th grades. There were cases of 7, 8 and 9 year olds who have never been registered because parents cannot afford school costs, can cover school needs for only a few of their children, or because children quit to work. Dismissals (not only after grade 8) are another reason for non-attendance. 3. Absences: Absenteeism is also a widespread problem according to the survey. Sporadic attendance affects more than a third of the children in the survey. The mean length of absences was 24 days, with a range of 10-150 days. A full 90 percent of absences lasted between 10 and 30 days. According to the survey, absenteeism affected more urban residents than rural residents and was more conunon among Yerevan students than in other cities.
 ANNEX 4 Page 2 of 6 For those students absent more than 10 school days, the top five reasons for these prolonged absences were, in order of importance: "health reasons" (66.8 percent); "poor physical conditions in the schools" (16.6 percent); "did not want to attend" (9.9 percent); "not being unable to meet costs" (6.1 percent), and "working to help the family" (6.1 percent). A few comments can be made regarding this data: * The response "poor physical conditions in the schools" was higher for Yerevan, than for areas outside of Yerevan, and twice more than for villages. In focus groups in cities, parents were more likely to complain about cold temperatures in the classrooms. In villages, parents said that they contribute fuel to heat the rooms. * According to the survey, the response "working to help the family" as a reason for absenteeism was given only by village households. During interviews and focus groups, rural schoolchildren and parents explained that agricultural responsibilities often take precedence over schooling. * No survey respondent gave "being unable to meet costs" as their first reason for absenteeism. Responses were even for urban and rural areas. However, parents in focus groups mentioned cases in which their inability to provide adequate clothes and shoes led to repeated absences of their children. * "Did not want to attend" comprised less than 1 percent of all village household responses but 6.4 percent of all city households. In focus groups and interviews with children, participants explained that absenteeism is linked to the decline in value of education. Chapter 2: Access to Education There are three main issues regarding access to education: physical access; costs of education and the household's ability to finance them, and access to essential inputs -- such as availability of textbooks. 1. Proximity to School: As expected, physical access to schools is not the main obstacle to access. According to the survey, 94.6 percent of the sample had a 10 grade school in their neighborhood or village. Only 1 percent of villages had no school. However qualitative findings suggests that residents of villages without a ten-grade school do not necessarily have easy access to schools in nearby villages. Mass transportation service is not adjusted to the school schedule and does not serve certain villages. As a result, children either walk to school and others take the bus -- sometimes arriving 20-30 minutes late each day. 2. Educational Expenses The main obstacle to access to education is the cost of schooling according to the survey. The main cost of education per child per year according to the survey is 88,000 drams (equivalent to US $215) with a range of 1500 dr. to 975,000 dr. (equivalent to a range of US $4 to US $2,374). Costs associated with clothing include: Clothing and shoes represent the largest single expenditure for respondents surveyed (41.6 percent of total expenses). During the focus groups, it was evident that there is strong societal pressure and a sense of competition among children and parents about clothes. Shoes are also an important status symbol. Without appropriate shoes or boots, children will often not be sent to school.
 ANNEX 4 Page 3 of 6 Textbooks: The mean amount spent on textbooks is 4,200 dr. (US $10.2) per child, with 11.3 percent saying that they spent no money on textbooks. The current price of textbooks (500-800 dr.) exceeds most parents' willingness to pay (mean of 356 dr.). Textbook costs add up quickly per grade and for families with many children. Additional lessons:3 The mean amount on these lessons per year per child according to the survey respondents is 26,681 dr. (US $65), yet 64.1 percent of households said that they did not spend any money on this item. Focus groups explained that the price of the lessons varies according to the grade and subject taught. More female students (20.6 percent) took additional lessons than males (17 percent) More city children (23.5 percent) took additional lessons than village children (10.3 percent). Fees for small repairs: A mean amount of 2,776 dr. was contributed per child per year as yet 64.8 percent of parents said that they did not contribute any money. This findings may have important implications for school self-financing plans. Informal payments were also mentioned during focus groups and interviews. Parents explained that, especially in the prestigious schools, parents provide presents and cash payments to teachers and school directors to ensure their goodwill towards their children, to increase grades or to ensure acceptance into a school. 3. Financine Education A full 46.6 percent of parents believe that they are unable to meet the costs of schooling. The picture worsens to 50 percent for parents with three or more children. Top sources of income for covering at least some of school expenses were: current income (75%/6), selling of personal belongings and property (over 33%/6), assistance from relatives (over 25%), savings (20%), and borrowed money without interest (16%). According to the focus groups, parents get more jobs, and children work to cover costs. Rural residents complained of that the seasonal lack of cash is a main impediment for meeting school costs in September. 4. Access to Essential Inputs: Textbooks Access to textbooks is considered to be the second greatest problem facing households, according to the survey respondents. Interestingly, availability is considered the main problem by 52 percent of the sample. In focus groups, dissatisfaction was also linked to high prices, physical appearance and content of textbooks. As a result of difficulties of access, 62 percent of the sample did not have a complete set of textbooks. The situation is worse in rural areas where 23.4 percent of households had a complete set of books than in urban areas where 46.6 percent had a complete set. Even in Yerevan, less than half of the students had a compete set of books. According to focus groups, sharing textbooks was the most widespread means of coping with the lack of textbooks. Yet sharing was mostly considered to be inconvenient and to have a negative impact on quality of education according to the focus groups. 5. Vulnerable Children, the Poor While teachers are believed to know who are the poor children in their communities, there is no evidence that the poorest are being targeted for assistance. In education, there is evidence of great socio-economic differentiation between the poor and the wealthy. Yet targeting is difficult because 46.6 percent of the parents in the survey believe that they were unable to provide for their children's school needs. Disabled children Over 50 percent of respondents said they are willing to consider mainstreaming students with physical disabilities. Expectations from Education According to the focus groups, some of parents' expectations from schools include: Free basic education: This expectation is shaped by the Soviet experience. Parents deplore rising costs. Teach basic knowledge or more: While some believe only basic skills are necessary, others believe schools should teach how to think and provide information about the world. Preparation for higher education: The value of general education is closely linked to access to higher education and expectations of social mobility. Today, higher education is believed to be no longer open for even bright students who are not rich. Even if access were provided, some parents asked what good is higher education if it does not lead to higher earnings. Socialization, including teaching discipline and becoming a good citizen, are also expected from schools. Schools are expected to stand in apposition to and as a protection from 'the street,' especially in grades 8-10 for both rural and urban children. However, schools are not always the sanctuaries that parents wish they were. Art, Music and Crafts: The full development of a child includes, according to parents, the nurturing of their creative and artistic talents such as music, art, crafts and sports. 2. Value of education While the inherent value of education remains high among many parents, the importance of education varies according to two types of criteria: merit: Many parents and teachers said that better performing kids get priority for support. gender: For girls, education is considered to be a great asset. An educated woman is expected to be a better spouse -- make better decisions and assist her children with their education. In both cities and villages, even if girls are not expected to work, higher education grants status to the family into which she marries. In urban areas, women also said that girls need education to gain "a degree of independence," and "to be prepared for life." For boys, as future providers, the value of education seems more closely linked to a debate over expected earnings. 3. Oualitv of Education Issues related to decreasing quality of education mentioned by parents in focus groups included: * The lack of books and textbook sharing; * Low salaries of teachers results in lower status and lower motivation of teachers which in turn leads to teacher absenteeism, lack of preparation of classes and lack of discipline; Additional classes are perceived as a symptom of declining quality of school-based education. Rural schools are worse affected by a decline in quality because: * Village schools rely on local labor, specialists or not, to teach. As a result, many non-specialists teach and some basic topics are not being taught at all; * Lower availability of textbooks; and * Less access to additional classes.

HoNwever this involvement is mostly limited to the home and does not extend to management of the school. Mothers traditionally assist their children with homework, attend meetings and, in lower grades, oversee school activities. Fathers said they usually limit their interactions to checking grades and making decisions regarding higher education and choices of profession. They are also called upon to make cash and labor contributions. Survey results suggest that most parents regularly communicate with school representatives. 2. Formal Meetin2s and Councils: Over the past year, 69 percent of surveyed parents visited the school once a month or more. In addition, the survey found that school parent councils4 exist in over half the schools (52.6 percent). Of those who said there was a council, 47 percent said that they attended the meetings last year. Attendance however was particularly low in Yerevan. In focus groups, parents discussed the role of the class councils. Class councils address disciplinary issues, results of children, money collection for building repairs, textbooks and other non-pedagogical issues. doc.repnme: Armenia - Education Financing and Management Reform Project
doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Education Financing and Management Reform Project for Armenia are to (a) improve the quality of general education by promoting school-level initiatives, by increasing opportunities and incentives for innovation throughout the system, and by improving the supply of textbooks and teaching materials; and (b) help build the necessary institutional framework and capacity at all levels to operate the basic education system efficiently, equitably, and sustainably. The first component improves textbook production and distribution by financing the following: (1) purchasing and distributing core textbooks for general education grades 1-10 to schools over a four-year period; (2) providing equipment and technical assistance to establish a computerized system for consolidating textbook orders; (3) providing technical assistance and training in curriculum design and preparation of publishers guidelines; (4) providing technical assistance and training for bid administrators, bid evaluators, authors, and publishers in book procurement; and (5) providing training and information for school directors, teachers, and parents in managing school-based revolving funds and in allocating subsidies to poor students. The second component supports detailed design, piloting, and implementation of the government's strategy for reforming the general education system. Its sub-components will increase efficiency by rationalizing schools and staffing; and improve resource mobilization and school performance by granting schools legal and financial autonomy.
